thread.title: Cybersecurity specialists in high demand
thread.title_full: Cybersecurity specialists in high demand | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Cybersecurity specialists in high demand
text:
With businesses looking to secure their systems and information, demand for security specialists is picking up, according to the Hays Quarterly Hotspots data for October to December 2015 released today.
Higher adoption of wireless and cloud-based solutions is also feeding the appetite for specialists, the report adds.
Hays senior regional director Peter Noblet said there had been “low double-digit’’ growth in demand for security engineers in the past three to six months.
“You are constantly seeing more high-profile cases of data theft and it’s certainly front of mind for a lot of organisations,’’ he said.
Mr Noblet added that premium salaries and rates were being paid for those with skills in UX/UI and Ruby on Rails.
“Security engineers, firewall experts, cyber security — with the prevalence in digital projects those areas are really attracting a bit more of a premium.’’
Just last week, retailer David Jones revealed its website had been hacked and private customer information stolen.
Harvey Nash APAC managing director Bridget Gray said there had been a 15 per cent increase in demand for security engineers over the past quarter. “Companies are starting to understand that hacking is now a real threat and they need to do everything they can to ensure that they do not end up in the headlines,’’ she said.
Spark Recruitment director Luke Singleton said demand was also being driven by rapid advances of counter-threat technologies such as security hardware and devices that include machine-based learning (AI) capabilities.
“As businesses make their interactions with customers more web or mobile-based this gives them greater exposure, everyone is a target,’’ he said.
The overall Australian IT recruitment market remains “highly active’’ with increased permanent hiring intentions in project services a standout, the report adds.
The lifting of the permanent recruitment freeze in the federal government has led to more permanent roles, with software development seen as a hot spot as organisations act to retain IP.
The other ICT hot spots identified by the Hays report are: software engineers, .NET web developers, senior developers, DevOps engineers, VMware Horizon View/VDI engineers, SharePoint administrators, SCCM engineers as well as business analysts, project managers and change managers.
